header.seo: Flipping The Switch | Aftermath: Puerto Ricans Rebuild After Maria
header.subtitle: Six months post-Maria, thousands Puerto Ricans are still in the dark. For months locals have taken the fallen electrical grid into their own hands instead of waiting on officials, bringing the island back into the light.

text.value: “I thought I was never going to see light in my home again,” said Elsia Cruz Torruellas, 65, standing on the front porch of her beige house, looking out at the electrical wires that had just been lifted from the ground and reconnected by a man she had known for only a few minutes.

Alberto de Jesus Mercado, the man who brought light back into her home, is 59-year-old electrician and environmental activist who has taken it upon himself to bring power back to dozens of Puerto Ricans who are still in the dark.

It had been six months since Cruz Torruellas’ home in Vega Baja, Puerto Rico lost power during Hurricane Irma. Hurricane Maria came through 14 days later, toppling power posts and brought electrical wires down across her front yard and driveway, trapping her and her family inside the home.

“The cables didn’t let us leave the upstairs patio or the house,” said Torruellas’ daughter, Maritza Ramirez Cruz, 39. She and a cousin had to crawl underneath the cables to get out of the home and once they did, she realized they wouldn’t be able to get the car out of the garage because a power pole had fallen on top of their metal fence, onto the property.

They walked down the block onto the main road and found some workers from the Autoridad de Energía Eléctrica (“The Electric Power Authority”), known in english as the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority, Puerto Rico’s main energy supplier.
They begged the PREPA employees to help move the downed wires which would allow her mother to get out of the house and allow them to use their car.

The workers moved the wires just enough to let the rest of their family into the yard and give them access to the garage. The men laid the wires between the pickets of the fence, stringing them mid-air about five feet off the ground across the front entrance of the house. That was the last time they saw anyone from the power authority.
“We practically had to bring them by force, after that they never came back,” said Ramirez Cruz.

value.text: “We practically had to bring them by force, after that they never came back.”

text.value: For weeks, Cruz Torruellas called the power authority, trying to get workers to come fix the electrical pole that. It wasn’t safe for her 11-year-old grandson, Nahuel, to play in the yard.

A family friend recommended they call, Mercado, known colloquially as “Tito Kayak” the many activist protests he has launched from a kayak. Kayak has been a certified as an electrician for more than 30 years.
“When [PREPA] would actually answer her call, they would tell her that the issue had already been reported,” said Ramirez Cruz. “Other times the call would ‘drop.’”

The power outage was extremely difficult for her mother. Everyone in Puerto Rico struggled with the loss of power, but Cruz Torruellas depends on the internet to do her online work, such as maintaining her blog and participating in writers workshops. She also homeschools Nahuel and, in order to teach him and keep him up to speed with the public school curriculum, she needs basic access to online teaching materials for him, which just added onto the list of things she had to worry about after Maria.
But Kayak isn’t the only one doing this. Desperation across Puerto Rico has forced people to pick wires up themselves.

NPR and the Associated Press have reported stories from San Sebastián de las Vegas del Pepino on the far west side of the island to Coamo in the deep south where tired Puerto Ricans are fed up with waiting for FEMA and reconstruction crews to get to them.
Volunteers made up from active police chiefs and former utility workers to teachers and accountants have managed to restore power to thousands of homes through large brigades.

There is a difference between the self-proclaimed “Pepino Power Authority” in San Sebastian and the 50-person fleets in the town Cuomo and Kayak. San Sebastian and Cuomo are rural areas. Cuomo is high in the mountains and tough terrain has been a challenge to hurricane recovery. Cities like these places were expected to not have power for a while.

Kayak is restoring it alone, with an extra set of hands only when he perceives the job as difficult, in places that are said to already have power. He actively restoring power in homes that are located in regions marked as completed.

Because certain cities and municipalities (like the capital city of San Juan and its surrounding areas) have been reported as fully restored, homes like Cruz Torruellas’ have fallen through the cracks since everyone around her already had electricity. When authorities came in, Cruz Torruellas’ home was somehow the only one that didn’t get power back.
In mid-March, Kayak drove up to Cruz Torruellas’ home, distinguishable by its patterned accents painted in pink, same as her fence

Kayak lives a minimalist lifestyle, partially to lack of resource. He drives his daughter's green Jeep Grand Cherokee because he doesn’t own a car, and straps on a silver extension ladder with  thick yellow straps to the roof rack. He uses a makeshift pulley system to extend the ladder by tugging on the straps, eliminating his need for a partner.
He said he knew right after the hurricanes that it would take months for the island to fully regain power.

Kayak, who has been performing electrical work since he was 14, is certified by a vocational electrician training school called the Colegio de Peritos Electricistas de Puerto Rico. With his license, Kayak practices as an independent contractor. He typically works for local businesses and sometimes gets one-time contracts from large corporations, but he prefers his work restoring power for those hit by the hurricanes.

His first time restoring power for anyone was only a few weeks after Maria hit, to an elderly woman who had lost power during Hurricane Irma. Because of his job as an electrician, a friend asked Kayak to help reconnect power to her home in Manati, over an hour west from the capital. The woman lives with cancer and needed power so that she could use her dialysis machine. “That’s where it started,” he said.
Kayak has since then taken the government’s responsibility into his own hands.
“Geez, we can do this ourselves, for the community,’” he thought to himself. “It was so cool, the people were happy,” he said.

The Cruz family were among the 3.3 million Puerto Ricans who lost power during hurricanes Irma and Maria, which severely damaged the island’s electrical grid. Six months later, it has been reported that approximately 121,000 residents still don’t have power.

The day Maria hit initiated the beginning of the longest blackout in United States history. The entire island was without power for an estimated accumulation of 1,248 hours: 52 days. (An analysis from the Rhodium Group of the number of customers who lost service by the amount of time they were without it.)

Puerto Rico’s power grid is something that keeps coming up in the news as a main reason for the islands inability to regain and maintain electricity after the storms. Through the restoration process, sporadic blackouts have been a testament to the fragility of the commonwealth's power grid.

An unexpected February explosion at an electric substation blamed on “mechanical failures” left northern parts of the island without power soon after they regained it through recovery efforts. The explosion was reported to have hit another two substations, extending the blackout further, inducing a loss of hundreds of megawatts of energy.

Frequent smaller neighborhood blackouts are scattered and underreported, like in the Santurce district in the heart of San Juan that lasted over eight hours in the middle of March- the time when many thought that most people to have power fully restored. PREPA’s and other officials now project full restoration to take “at least until May.”
But why is it taking so long?

Puerto Rico’s grid suffered greatly after the back-to-back categories 4 and 5 hurricanes in September. The American Public Power Association reported the islands need for 50,000 utility poles and 6,500 miles of cables in an initial supply order placed by the USACE in October.

PREPA's increasing debt is responsible for the company running on equipment nearly three times older than the national industry standard, meaning that repair crews are attempting to fix equipment damaged by the hurricanes that was already long-overdue for replacement.

With about 80 percent of the electrical grid left destroyed, it will take a large chunk of time just to rebuild the system, especially in the mountainous regions, not even accounting for the amount of time needed to reinstall power into everyone's homes.

Puerto Ricans fear the restoration will not be completed before the island enters into its next hurricane season, which lasts from June to November. The six-month season of winds and rain will make the already vulnerable system susceptible to falling again.

Since the hurricanes, Puerto Rico’s debt crisis has been brought up in conversations dealing with disaster relief aid. The United States commonwealth has a $73 billion debt, due to a combination of a double digit unemployment rate, declining island population with mass migration to the mainland, the inability to devalue its currency to become more competitive and 40 percent of its population living below the poverty line.
PREPA, that filed for bankruptcy in July 2017 is responsible for $9 billion of that debt.
Because they are the only energy company on the island, government-run PREPA places a monopoly on the Puerto Rican people that has been instated for nearly 80 years.

The entity relies on purchasing imported fossil fuels and burning oil to generate electricity, not only contributing to pollution but, forcing customers to pay rates that follow foreign oil prices. In 2014, it was unable to pay for fuel and through many negotiations, unpopular bill increases were instituted to help pay the company’s debt while making no efforts to move toward its long-awaited shift toward renewable energy.

Previously, they have been placed under investigation with FBI by the Puerto Rican senate for fuel-purchasing irregularities and, most recently, with the Department of Justice by Governor Rosselló for crimes “against the public interest” in the January case involving a report by the United States Army Corps of Engineers that hidden reconstruction materials were being hoarded by PREPA in a supply warehouse set up in Palo Seco, just across the bay from Old San Juan.

The Army Corps sets up supply warehouses across the island to distribute equipment that helps reestablish the island’s power grid, but the materials were reportedly “out-of-stock” and not having access to them has delayed the restoration process.
Governor Rosselló put forward a plan to privatize PREPA in an effort to prevent similar issues from reoccurring and in an attempt to lessen the island’s debt.

“The Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority has become a heavy burden on our people, who are now hostage to its poor service and high cost. What we know today as the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority does not work and cannot continue to operate like this,” said Rosselló.

Privatizing PREPA would eliminate the governmental energy monopoly in place since World War II, but selling it off and allowing competitors to bid for the islands customers would cause the “largest restructuring of a public entity in U.S. history.”

Ricardo Santos Ramos, former president of Puerto Rico’s electrical workers union the Electrical Industry and Irrigation Workers Union, best known by its spanish acronym UTIER, compared the situation to cellular service suppliers. He said that the idea works well in theory and sounds attractive to a large population of the Puerto Rican people, but only because they don’t understand it holds negative repercussions.

“There is not a single country in the world where privatizing electricity and has lowered its cost,” he said, “energy will be more expensive if it is private.” Right now, he explained, PREPA sells energy at the price it costs to produce.

“If we privatize it, the private company is going to sell us what costs them, plus an increase to make the profit we will give them,” said Ramos. He is adamant that, being that they are an island, Puerto Rico needs to have its own, autonomous energy reserve. Independence from the foreign countries supplying fossil fuels, as well as autonomy from the US mainland so that the island becomes reliant on its own electricity and does not need to wait for aid from the federal government.
Ramos believed that not only will privatizing their power authority raise costs for consumers, but it also moves Puerto Rico further away from a long-promised shift to other forms of energy.
“Privatizing electrical power plants is to forever bury the possibility for us to make an orderly transition into renewable energy," said Ramos.
